Hi all,

Earlier in the year I kicked off a discussion about genome compati=
bility metrics (AKA distance or similarity metrics). SharpNeat 2 (SN2) is n=
earing release and allows metrics to be plugged and thus compared, there's =
a bit more to it than that and I'm currently writing some documentation to =
explain how this will work along with some issues to keep in mind, pros and=
 cons, etc.

Anyway in writing up this stuff I ended up documenting how the=
 original metric works, as described in the original NEAT paper in 2002. No=
w I've got a suspicion that this came up long ago but in that paper the dis=
tance is given as:

   d =3D c1*E/N + c2*D/N + c3*W

(E,D are the # of exce=
ss and disjoint genes. W is the total weight diff).

N is the number of gen=
es in the longest genome. So the contribution of excess/disjoint genes to d=
 is normalized. In Ken's original code this equation is commented out and r=
eplaced with the equivalent of:

   d =3D c1*E + c2*D + c3*W

This makes mo=
re sense to me, it puts far more emphasis on the difference in topology tha=
n the first version and is sort of related to edit distance and manhattan d=
istance. 

For the record SN1 also uses the latter equation and the other i=
mplementation I checked just now was ANJI2 which uses the former. Not sure =
what the implications of this are but I suspect it would have a significant=
 effect on speciation with secondary effects from there. Others may wish to=
 review the metric in their implementations.

Colin.
